messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 60 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Parameterized Spanning Tree Congestion

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this paper we study the Spanning Tree Congestion problem, where we are given a graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E) and are asked to find a spanning tree T𝑇T of minimum maximum congestion. Here, the congestion of an edge e∈T𝑒𝑇e\in T is the number of edges u​v∈E𝑢𝑣𝐸uv\in E such that the (unique) path from u𝑢u to v𝑣v in T𝑇T traverses e𝑒e. We consider this well-studied NP-hard problem from the point of view of (structural) parameterized complexity and obtain the following results: • We resolve a natural open problem by showing that Spanning Tree Congestion is not FPT parameterized by treewidth (under standard assumptions). More strongly, we present a generic reduction which applies to (almost) any parameter of the form “vertex-deletion distance to class 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}”, thus obtaining W[1]-hardness for parameters more restricted than treewidth, including tree-depth plus feedback vertex set, or incomparable to treewidth, such as twin cover. Via a slight tweak of the same reduction we also show that the problem is NP-complete on graphs of modular-width 444. • Even though it is known that Spanning Tree Congestion remains NP-hard on instances with only one vertex of unbounded degree, it is currently open whether the problem remains hard on bounded-degree graphs. We resolve this question by showing NP-hardness on graphs of maximum degree 888. • Complementing the problem’s W[1]-hardness for treewidth, we formulate an algorithm that runs in time roughly (k+w)𝒪​(w)superscript𝑘𝑤𝒪𝑤{(k+w)}^{\mathcal{O}(w)}, where k𝑘k is the desired congestion and w𝑤w the treewidth, improving a previous argument for parameter k+w𝑘𝑤k+w that was based on Courcelle’s theorem. This explicit algorithm pays off in two ways: it allows us to obtain an FPT approximation scheme for parameter treewidth, that is, a (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-approximation running in time roughly (w/ε)𝒪​(w)superscript𝑤𝜀𝒪𝑤{(w/\varepsilon)}^{\mathcal{O}(w)}; and it leads to an exact FPT algorithm for parameter clique-width+k𝑘+k via a Win/Win argument. • Finally, motivated by the problem’s hardness for most standard structural parameters, we present FPT algorithms for several more restricted cases, namely, for the parameters vertex-deletion distance to clique; vertex integrity; and feedback edge set, in the latter case also achieving a single-exponential running time dependence on the parameter.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 60 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 60"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Using petal-decompositions to build a low stretch spanning tree",
        "Ray shooting and other applications of spanning trees with low stabbing number",
        "Parameterized power vertex cover",
        "Parameterized (approximate) defective coloring",
        "An adaptive version of brandes’ algorithm for betweenness centrality",
        "Finding spanning trees with perfect matchings",
        "Approximation hardness of short symmetric instances of MAX-3SAT",
        "Parameterized complexity of the spanning tree congestion problem",
        "Parallel algorithms with optimal speedup for bounded treewidth",
        "Spanning tree congestion of k-outerplanar graphs",
        "A 3/2-approximation algorithm for finding spanning trees with many leaves in cubic graphs",
        "Low-stretch spanning trees of graphs with bounded width",
        "Tree spanners",
        "Minimum congestion spanning trees of grids and discrete toruses",
        "Spanning tree congestion and computation of generalized györi-lovász partition",
        "FPT approximation using treewidth: Capacitated vertex cover, target set selection and vector dominating set",
        "The monadic second-order logic of graphs. i. recognizable sets of finite graphs",
        "Upper bounds to the clique width of graphs",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "Spanning trees with few branch vertices",
        "Graph Theory, volume 173 of Graduate texts in mathematics",
        "Cluster vertex deletion: A parameterization between vertex cover and clique-width",
        "Spanners in sparse graphs",
        "Lower-stretch spanning trees",
        "Approximating minimum max-stretch spanning trees on unweighted graphs",
        "Tree spanners in planar graphs",
        "The complexity ecology of parameters: An illustration using bounded max leaf number",
        "Clique-width is np-complete",
        "Spanners of bounded degree graphs",
        "Parameterized algorithms for parity games",
        "Parameterized algorithms for modular-width",
        "Improving vertex cover as a graph parameter",
        "Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness",
        "Spanning trees with bounded number of branch vertices",
        "An FPT algorithm for spanning trees with few branch vertices parameterized by modular-width",
        "The tree-width of clique-width bounded graphs without Kn,nsubscript𝐾𝑛𝑛K_{n,n}",
        "Spanning trees with edge conflicts and wireless connectivity",
        "On tree congestion of graphs",
        "Bin packing with fixed number of bins revisited",
        "Integer programming with a fixed number of variables",
        "Spanning trees with many leaves",
        "Approximating spanning tree congestion on graphs with polylog degree",
        "A note on approximation of spanning tree congestion",
        "A single-exponential time 2-approximation algorithm for treewidth",
        "Spanning tree congestion of rook’s graphs",
        "On spanning tree congestion of graphs",
        "Algorithmic meta-theorems for restrictions of treewidth",
        "Parameterized approximation schemes using graph widths",
        "Minimum stable cut and treewidth",
        "Spanning tree congestion of the hypercube",
        "In the complement of a dominating set",
        "On spanning tree congestion",
        "Better hardness results for the minimum spanning tree congestion problem",
        "A new dynamic programming approach for spanning trees with chain constraints and beyond",
        "Hardness results and an exact exponential algorithm for the spanning tree congestion problem",
        "Minimal congestion trees",
        "Minimum congestion spanning trees in planar graphs",
        "A survey on spanning tree congestion",
        "A variation on the min cut linear arrangement problem",
        "Approximating minimum bounded degree spanning trees to within one of optimal"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 60 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Parameterized Spanning Tree Congestion, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
